reviewText:
Early Access Review

You're the Earth's single hope!
If the Solus Project would be like any other project you do for a class, then this would easily get an A+.

Side Note | Important for some
The lack of registered hours on this game is because I had no choice but to play it offline.

Lore
Humanity no longer has a home. Earth has been destroyed, and all that remains of it is on a nomadic fleet of ships searching for a place to rebuild their civilization. In The Solus Project, you take on the role of a surveying team charting an Earthlike planet that may just prove suitable for humanity’s resettlement. Disaster strikes suddenly and you find yourself marooned on the surface of Gliese. Armed with only the most basic knowledge of the dangers the planet holds, you must set out to solve the mystery of the destruction of your ship, and contact your fleet for rescue.

You were sent to save the mankind.
Who will save  you  now?

Gameplay
Solus Project is a single player, first person survival game. Solus Project takes place in an alien alike prehistoric, colourful sci-fi setting. As stated about the sci-fi setting and all, The Solus Project could easily be mistaken for another sci-fi themed survival game. As soon as you start, you're greeted by your PDA which gives you basic information to get you going in the unknown, as well as some tips about survival.

It might have the same mechanics as all survival games such as finding food and water, be careful with your character's temperature and get enough sleep. One of the differences here, and quite a big one, is the need to create buildings. The shelter itself is not permanent. You're a nomad. Why?

Because the objective of this game, is to explore, explore and explore! But not generated lands! It's one, big planet full of rich alien foliage, mountains of impressive sizes giving quite a challenge for the player to reach their top. Upon doing so, the view is fantastic especially with the weather the developers have implemented that gives the game even more charm, I simply love the meteor showers with an undescribable feeling. Though the player must be careful as the temperature as well changes and gives more discomfort, giving more difficulty.

The lack of mini-map gives as well an interesting feeling, since like in the old days, you're let with the single option, that one option being to draw your own maps with the explored areas.

For the achievers, there is a multitude of secrets and hidden areas ready to be plundered, with quite a reward. More lore. Yet.. it's pretty short without exploring and fiddling around with every bit, you can complete it fast, in an hour or so. Don't fret! Part two is here so the hours have been extended. Have fun exploring, for the mankind!

Graphics
As stated above, the whole relief of this planet is not only the reward itself for exploring, but something mandatory as soon as you're in-game. It's quite stunning to see such a beautiful unknown, which makes you want more and more. The Unreal Engine 4 really pays off on this one, especially maxed all out, to let your eyes feast on every little detail. The color palette used for this game surprises me as well, a mix of orange and gray, with lots of blue, metal there and there which are the ambient's mains and it's delicious. Those are the mains, while the secondaries are the ones used for the foliage, items and so on. Talking about relief

OST & SFX
This game’s sound design is just superb. The soundtrack is incredibly atmospheric and memorable. The sound effects are incredibly satisfying. The music just adds so much energy and life to the world, as any good soundtrack should. It’s a great listen to while exploring caves and strange structures. Such a great one that I just stared at the scenery and let the time flow with the tune playing.

Should you buy it?
Overall, Solus Project is out of this world(pun intended)! In my honest opinion, it is a nice experience and take on the survival genre, which is focused more on exploration. If you'd like to experience something new with the same mechanisms, this is your cup of tea, worth the whole sip. Full price recommended.

Early Access Review

Verdict: A Galactic success story.

Before I describe to you, as to why the Solus Project is a phenomenal game, I must admit that I was at first dubious as to how immersive the gameplay would feel and how much replayibility it would have. Having played for almost 3 hours, I realise my concerns were unfounded and here is why:

Simulation

You start the game marooned on an alien world but it has traces that an Egyptian type civilisation once inhabited this world. Hieroglyphics depicting gods being praised by their worshippers adorn the walls of the the subterranean underworld. Water drips down the stalagmites, its drops signifying health reguvenation is close at hand. Alien plant species strike from the shadows, breaking your visor and splattering it with blood. You will need a medkit or sleep to heal your wounds from this beautiful yet deadly ecosystem.

Visuals

The game is near photorealistic in its depiction of life on this hostile planet. The sea glistens and undulates to the rhythem of the tide, a day and night cycle creates unimanginably gorgeous panoramic scenes, cave interiors beckon to be explored with their incredible colour palettes and glistening stones. Asteroid strikes light up the sky with trails of fire and smoke, striking nearby scarring the landscape with their tremendous force. Of all the games in my librabry, this is by far the most visually stunning game I own (80+ games with a GTX 980)

Some screenshots:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=627672742

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=627698265

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=627700934

Adventure

Whilst this is no sandbox, the parametres to explore are wide and there is a deep sense of accomplishment when you discover a humanoid clutching a sword which can be used for a multitude of purposes. Kindling can be lit to ensure you keep warm after suffering from hypothermia, or shade can be used to reduce the impact of heat stroke. An advanced monitoring device held in your characters left hand indicates all your vital signs and even reminds you that you need to sleep!

Performance

This game does not perform like an EA game. There is no stuttering, no erratic fps drops, no sudden crash. It runs silky smooth even during natural events such as  earthquakes, tornadoes etc. On my GTX 980 laptop I'm getting 50fps at 3k resolution.

Value

For just under £10 this game is an absolute steal! The production values are extremely high for such a modestly priced game. Bear in mind, during EA content is being released episodically until May (the release date).

Conclusion

If you love the following themes buy this game: Atmospheric, survival, Simulation, Aliens, Galactic, Crafting, Exploration, Beautiful and Classic

Edit: Just completed the first part in 3.5 hours. It would have taken me 5-6 hours had I explored more rather than stick to the objective. Great value for money!

The Solus Project:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

After the earth has been destroyed, the faith of mankind is now relying on a small fleet of colony ships near Pluto! Your job is to scout planets to determine if one of them is suitable for human habitation. Well, as you approach one of them, your ship is hit by something coming from below and you just manage to reach the escape pod in time. As you fall rather quickly towards it, you keep wondering what you are going to find out upon impact!

The Solus Project is a First Person/Survival/Exploring game with absolutely stunning visuals. At the start of the game, you will see a couple of splendid introduction videos from the destruction of earth to your crash landing. Then, you will step onto this glorious scenery of the planet Gliese-6143-C.

All is beautiful but you really have nothing on you and your first task is to scavenge for useful items around the crash site. The first one you find is a survival device; a PDA which will tell you when to eat, drink, sleep, the outside temperature, can decrypt alien writing and other useful options.  You will be lead to specific destinations and will be shown where you can find food, water and how to craft items too. The game atmosphere is just brilliant - either you are on the surface of the planet or deep in the caves. The weather element is well done, too. You might experience a meteor shower, lighting and other extreme weather on the planet surface. Try to gather food (cans of food or plants) before entering the cavern just to be on the safe side. Oh, and be careful not to get wet too often especially in a cold environment like caverns. This is a great recipe for hypothermia!

The game does have a puzzle element to it, but to be honest they are not very difficult (as far as I have progressed) but make sure to read all the notes as well as the Alien symbols which can provide you with great intel; your PDA is very handy for that.

You will only be able to store up to 12 items in your inventory at the Start of the game, which is a bit of a bugger. I like to gather as many items as I can and you never know when you might need them.

Graphically this game is stunning. Mouse and keyboard for the controls and great sound effects all round. Also, you can set whatever level you want to play, from easy to hard.

-	Very good atmosphere

The Solus Project is a very good First Person exploration game with a good story and splendid visuals! It is time for you to land on the planet Gliese! You won’t regret it!

Tags: Early Access, Adventure, Survival, Indie, Sci-Fi, Simulation, Exploration, First-Person, Story Rich, Singleplayer, Survival Horror

IntroductionYou play as a lone survivor of a crashed ship on a strange (and for the most part uninhabited) alien planet.  Tasked with finding a way get back home, you will face harsh environments and uncover timely mysteries.

OverviewIf you want a casual atmospheric survival game set in space, look no further! This is one of the most beautiful and immersive games I have played in quite some time. While it’s no sandbox like some others with similar concepts, what The Solus Project has to offer is quite interesting.

The levels are crafted even to the smallest detail, focusing on a more linear approach instead of sandbox survival. Don’t be fooled though, hidden within these levels are multitudes of secrets waiting to be found.

The crafting system is not too complex but was detailed enough to keep me interested. Things you find on the islands can be combined, for example, you use two rocks to make a sharp rock and use that sharp rock on a closed can of food to open it. Recourses are scarce, so be careful what you do (I accidentally burned some important material by using a torch on it…. oops)

The environment is very complex and includes all sorts of weather; scorching heat, tornadoes, storms, and even meteors. This is without a doubt the best feature that this game has to offer in my opinion. Another detailed part of the Solus Project is the in-depth day/night cycle. Every detail is there: temperatures, winds, humidity, and cloud coverage.  Very unforgiving: a single mistake can get you killed.

This game is in early access at the time I write this review, and content is being added regularly by active devs. I only found a few problems with the game: The running sometimes glitches (and movement in general is a little awkward) and Saves are not working properly for me (I’m not sure when the game saves and when it does. I thought I saved at a shrine, only to find myself back at the starting area when I started up again.)

SummaryOverall, I recommend that you give this a try if you enjoy atmospheric games with phenomenal attention to details.

cool mysterious sci-fi exploration game with some survival elements.

so far there hasn't been any action yet, just exploring islands, caves and alien architecture.
I really dig the the atmosphere they're trying to create with this game, a lot of the story comes from the environment and the things you discover. cons:

Early Access Review

Surprisingly good game if you like an exploration game where everything is atmosphere and story based. Although its not under the genre it should be considered a mystery game as well.

This is a very good exploration game where you alone are exploring this alien planets surface. Most of the gameplay involves the environment of the levels itself. When it comes to level design and feel this game is unique and i can't think of anything similar to it. The environments design is absolutely cool with full day and night cycles with dynamic weather(plus tornados). The surface of the planet does have an alien feel and what you find on the planet is definantly interesting and engaging. The levels span from beautiful all the way to eerie. The detail put into the alien appearance of the surface and structures is amazing especially when it comes to the alien technology that you will come across.

As you explore you find mysterious pieces of a civilization whos history you piece together through writings and pictures. This story requires you to manually put the words and pictures together to get things to make sense. It pretty much is like learning of ancient civilizations on earth through the artifacts we've uncovered. This method is of story telling is not used often so you'll be in for a treat with this one.

This is a casual game that is definantly worth a try. Unless you need continious action because it is very lonely on this planet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Starts off with a nice story line. You begin on an alien planet and need to survive by gathering supplies into your backpack and/or gathering them in a cave.

The nights are very cold and the days are warm, so at night you need to keep warm. You do this by finding the necessary supplies then using them to stay safe. Once you do so, you can begin to explore more safely.

There are puzzles, traps, secrets, and more along the way. Backstory is provided via pages strewn around from the wreakage. Some story is also provided by alien structures/monuments. The rest of the story is provided by voice.

The sound effects and music are all really good and help pull you into it.

As this review is from Early Access, there's currently some bugs. Nothing major.

But, some annoying things could be better such as when getting wet its quite difficult to read the in-game UI as there's these big water droplets in the way that may not be moving out of the way.

The water droplet animation is REALLY bad.

And some other things... what they improve or fix in the end just isn't known at this time.

You can jump and move around at will. Into the water you go! The ONLY invisible walls I've noticed are deep at sea.

There's plenty more to find out for yourself...

Overall, definitely recommended. I haven't wanted to play a survival based game until now. This one is good.

(Its best to have a short review for this game as the more you read the more its going to take away from the discovery aspect of it which is very important here.)

Early Access Review

A fantastic and immersive story driven survival game, The Solus Project is something special in a world filled with survival sandboxes.
Stranded on an alien world, humanity's dwindling hope for survival must uncover the mysteries of an ancient civilization while battling a hostile environment, and solving strange puzzles.

Graphically, the game is amazing. The landscapes are alien and beautiful, and the night sky is breathtaking.
The music and sound effects add a level of eeriness to the world that really drives home the feeling that you are not on Earth.

The gameplay is survival with food, water, sleep, and body temperature all while balancing the need to always progress and explore.

All in all, it is a satisfying experience.

Pure awesome!! I cant stress enough how good this is, especially, for an early access game. Too many times you see altered artwork of the worlds and videos that always llok 10x better than the actual game. So far, this game looks good, runs good, makes sense, et al. Everything that you expect out of a game - the basics - are already done correctly.

Now, you crashed on a fairly hospitable planet. Lucky you. Plus you have one main tool and there are survival notes that got scattered all over the palce. So, the main tool you use is a PDA. And its a sweet little tool. It scans an object when you look at it, tells you how your health is, receives incoming satellite messages, recordings, is used as your save tool (sleeping will automatically save), and more. When you need to select other options, like sleeping, it can cover the full screen. What I like about this is that it feels and acts just like an important tool in the field should. I love a good survival game, too bad this isn't one.

The map limits you to a few narrow corridors. What passes for the survival element is your fading food, water, and sleep meters. Replenishing these feels more like a chore than an adventure. There are no real options available: just hunt around for cans of food, refill your water bottles time and again, and try to figure out how the designer intended you to worm your way into the next area. Rinse and repeat.

The opening and cut scenes are tedious, but the game play graphics are great.

I wouldn't recommend this game. Well, unless you think it's fun to look for keys to unlock the next area while gathering conveniently placed food/water to reset your food and water timers.

If your idea of survival involves wide ranging choices, random discoveries, random dangers, and the freedom to venture into the forest or scrounge along the beach, forget it.

Solus, where to start.

The direction of the game is a unique one. You are one of the last humans alive in the universe. You crash land on an alien beach (ARK) and have to use basic crafting supplies to survive (ARK). As you progress alien sounds and relics empower and guide your path to find a benevolent intelligence at work.

The strengths of this game include a bizarre alien weather system, which makes survival interesting and unpredictable. One minute you're burning hot, the next you're freezing. You can retreat to various safe areas, which typically coincide with save points, but you will encounter a dark presence, which leaves you few options for a safe retreat.

As survival games go, this one has puzzles that remind me strongly of any of the recent Metroid games. (I say recent, I think back to Gamecube and Nintendo 64) The puzzles require intelligence and planning. You will eventually have more locks than keys. Choose wisely! (spoiler)

The textures (graphics) leave a little to be desired, but as you go you get swept up in the big picture. There are very few glitches (if any, I have encountered none) and many hours to be derived between searching for secrets, dodging the weather, hunting for aliens, and finding interesting new things to craft.

This game gets 5/5 from me. Definitely recommended.
